translated: Tripiá¹­aka Master from the Western Regions, Probationary Chamberlain for Ceremonials, Chief Minister for Making Loud Announcements, and Grand Master for Opening the Court
Compiled by Åšramaá¹‡a Shi Daoshi of Ximing Temple
The records of the Wei and Wu dynasties refer to the two capitals of Luoyang and Jianye. Cao Pi, whose courtesy name was Zixuan,
was a person from Qiao in Pei Commandery. He was the son of Cao Cao, the Chancellor of the Han Dynasty.
On the day of his birth, there was a blue cloud shaped like a carriage canopy.
It hovered above him all day, a deep blue color.
Those who interpreted the qi called it
a sign of utmost nobility, not an omen for a mere official.
At the age of eight, he was good at writing.
He succeeded to the position of chancellor and became the King of Wei.
He accepted the abdication of the Later Han Dynasty.
He changed the name to Wei.
He still had his capital in Luoyang.
The number of years of the Han Dynasty came to an end.
The Five Peaks became the two sacrifices.
In the Huangchu era, the Wei Dynasty accepted the abdication.
The Nine Pastures were thus divided into three parts.
The Sun clan established Wu.
They relied on the Yangtze River to plan for the world.
Liu Zong, the King of Shu,
Relying on the Jianmen Pass, wanted to settle the Central Plains.
The claws and fangs of a tiger lying down, the majestic power of a dragon lying down.
Each occupies one domain, with the intention of swallowing each other.
Competing to control the boundaries, they strictly guard the passes and checkpoints.
Extensively recruiting talented people to serve as their arms and legs.
Thickly rewarding the wise and talented, they treat them as treasures of the state.
The excellent craftsmen and wonderful Dharma have returned together.
Seng Hui arrived in Wu.
The relics shine with spiritual power on the Jiang Zuo region.
KÄrá¹£aka traveled to Wei.
The precepts are widely proclaimed in Luoyang.
The Vinaya has been greatly practiced since then.
The reason for the establishment of Jian Chu is that the translators follow the world.
Still using the local dialects, the sutras are translated according to the times.
Therefore, the titles are named after Wu and Shu.
The repeated translations begin with this, and the streams divide from here.
The loss of the translator's name is due to this.
Since the three kingdoms of Wei, Shu, and Wu were established,
Why is it that Shu alone has no record of the era?
How could it be that the Buddha's sun shines in the sky but those without conditions cannot see it?
The Dharma thunder shakes the earth but those next to it do not hear it?
Although the old records note the Sutra of the Great PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ, the ÅšÅ«raá¹ƒgama-sÅ«tra, and other sÅ«tras translated in Shu,
they are still lacking in the translator's name and era.
Even if one wishes to record them, they do not know what to rely on.
They are pushed into the category of lost translations.
Therefore, there is no separate record.
Sun Quan, courtesy name Zhongmou,
was from Fuchun in Wu County.
His family served the Wu state.
On the east side of his family's tomb, there were often divine lights and clouds.
Moreover, when Quan was first in the womb,
his mother dreamed that her intestines were drawn out and coiled around the Wu Chang Gate.
The crowd all called it the rise of the Sun family.
When Quan was born, his eyes had unusual light, a square jaw, and a large mouth.
His father found it strange.
Quan succeeded Wang.
He crossed over Min and Yue, and his capital was in Douniu.
He enfeoffed the feudal lords and established a reign period.
He faced the sea and mountains, and as the ruler of the south, he was called Wu.
He moved the capital to Moling and renamed it Jianye.
The Wei Dynasty succeeded the Han after two years, and Quan established it.
It had four rulers for fifty-nine years.
Hao reigned for two years, then the Wei Dynasty abdicated to the Jin.
The Jin Dynasty was established for fifteen years, and Wu was pacified.
If divided by years, Hao's fourteenth year should have entered the Jin Dynasty.
Now, the records are collected and concluded as the Wu Record.ğŸ”½From the first year of Emperor Wen's Huangchu era, the jiazi year,
to the first year of Emperor Yuan's Xianxi era, the jiashen year,
there were five rulers for forty-five years.
Ten people, both clergy and laity,
produced sutras, vinaya, karman, and the old lost translations.
A total of three hundred twelve texts.
Four hundred and eighty-three scrolls.
The two dynasties of Wei and Wu, the nine rulers, and the two capital city records are thus compiled.

DharmakÄla's MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika Precepts, one fascicle, first translation, seen in Zhu Daozu's Wei History Record. Right, one fascicle. Monk DharmakÄla of Central India.
Wei means Dharma Time.
Intelligent and wise from a young age, with an extraordinary appearance.
After reading a book once, he understood the text and meaning completely.

Proficient in the four Vedas, astronomy, meteorology, calendrical calculations, and divination, he was knowledgeable in all changes and transformations. He considered that he had exhausted all that could be known in the world.
At the age of twenty-five, he entered a monastery.
He encountered the Abhidharma-há¹›daya of DharmaÅ›reá¹£á¹­hin.
He casually picked it up to read it.
He was confused and did not understand.
He carefully reviewed it again and again, but it only made him more confused.
He then sighed and said,
The Buddha's teachings are profound and discuss the three times.
He then left home.
He recited the scriptures of the Mahayana and Hinayana, as well as the Vinaya Piá¹­aka.
He traveled and taught to Luoyang.
At that time, although there was Buddhism in the Wei territory, the Dharma wind had become distorted.
There were also many monks who had not yet received the precepts of refuge.
They only shaved their heads as a way to be different from ordinary people.
Even if they held confession ceremonies, it was the same as worshipping deities.
When KÄlayaÅ›as arrived, he greatly promoted Buddhism.
The monks requested him to translate the Vinaya.
KÄlayaÅ›as thought that the Vinaya Piá¹­aka had too many rules and the text was too extensive. If Buddhism had not flourished, they would definitely not have accepted it.
In the Jiaping years, he translated this one-fascicle version of the PrÄtimoká¹£a at Baima Temple.
It was sufficient for the morning and evening.
This was the beginning of the precepts in China.
Kang Sengkai's two-fascicle Sutra of Questions by the Elder Ugra, second translation.

A total of 152 fascicles.ğŸ”½In the era of Emperor Wen of the Wei Dynasty.
UpÄsaka Zhi Qian of Yuezhi.
Style name Gongming.
Also known as Yue.
At the end of the Han Dynasty, he studied under Zhi Liang in Luoyang.
Liang's style name was Jiming.
Ming studied under Zhi Chen.
Chen has already been seen in the Han Dynasty records.
The world says that there are not more than three people who know everything.
Zhi Qian thoroughly read the scriptures and did not fail to study them in detail.
He practiced many worldly skills.
He studied various foreign writings and understood the languages of the Six States.
He was thin and dark, with small eyes and a lot of white in them, but with bright yellow pupils.
At that time, people made a saying about him:
Zhi Lang's eyes are yellow.
Although his body is small, he is a treasure of wisdom.
At the end of the Han Dynasty, he avoided the chaos and returned to Wu.
Sun Quan heard of his talent and wisdom and summoned him to meet him.
He was very pleased with him and immediately appointed him as a professor.
He was ordered to assist the Crown Prince.
Together with Wei Yao and others, he fully assisted and advised.
He was of great benefit.
But Jian was born in the Western Regions.
Therefore, the Wu History does not record him.
He was entrusted with power but his achievements were not recorded.
This is the fault of the historians.
How could it be the intention of the Emperor?
As the ruler of the world,
if one feels the use of talents suitable for worldly affairs, one bestows rank upon them.
Their names are recorded in bamboo and silk. How can the distinction between Chinese and barbarians be a limit, and why are they not recorded in the official histories?
Moreover, Ye Gong.
His son Gao loved dragons.
The heavenly dragon then descended for him.
Since he did not treat the people of the barbarians with courtesy,
it is difficult to expect their king to submit to civilization.
However, using the bones of a dead horse to obtain a fine horse,
placing the technique of nine nines to wait for wise talents.
This is probably the Emperor's own deletion from ancient times to the present, to include and swallow, to cut out.
Jian, although the great teaching was practiced,
many scriptures were still in Sanskrit and had not been fully translated.
Since he was already proficient in the local dialect,
he further collected various old translations of sutras and translated them into the Wu dialect.
From the first year of Huangwu to the end of Jianxing,
a total of more than thirty years.
The sutras he translated include Vimalakirti Sutra, Mahaparinirvana Sutra, Dharmapada, Sutra of the Past and Future, and so on.
The records of the Tripitaka Master Seng You only list thirty-six texts.
The Biographies of Eminent Monks compiled by Hui Jiao only mentions forty-nine sutras.
Fang Guang searched through various miscellaneous records.
From the Sutra in Forty-two Sections onwards, they are miscellaneous sutras revealed by separate records and are appended to the present record.
Counting the previous biographies and records, there are thirty-six texts.
Or forty-nine sutras.

It seems that what he translated later was correct, but many of the earlier translations used Sanskrit. However, the intention and substance of the records and descriptions of what he heard and saw are slightly different, and the lists of texts have many differences in what is included and excluded.
Each preserves one version, leading to confusion in acceptance and rejection.
Moreover, the ocean of Dharma is vast, and matters are gathered like drops of water.
Having extensively searched and seen the ancient texts, he has listed them all.
And Kang Senghui's translations of sutras skillfully capture the holy meaning, with elegant language and great talent.
He also composed the three-line Sanskrit chants for the Bodhisattvas based on the Sutra of Immeasurable Life and the Sutra of the Past and Present.
Even today, they are still practiced in the Jiang and Huai regions. He also annotated the sutras on the equality of the fundamental nature of life and death.ğŸ”½And prefaces.
Kang Senghui's Sutra of the Collection of the Six Perfections in nine scrolls, also called the Sutra of the Six Perfections,ğŸ”½also called the Sutra of the Perfections,
also called the Sutra of the Miscellaneous Perfections.
Seen in the records of Zhu Daozu and the Records of the Tripiá¹­aka. The Wu-style sutras in five scrolls are the Small Perfection of Wisdom Sutra.
Seen in the records of the collection of the Tripiá¹­aka. The Sutra on the Pure Conduct of Bodhisattvas in two scrolls was translated in the years of the Red Bird era.
The chapter on the precious knots of the Great Collection.
Sometimes it is simply called the Sutra on Pure Precepts.
Seen in the records of Zhu Daozu and the Wu catalog. The Sutra of Miscellaneous Parables in two scrolls, sometimes without the word collection.
Seen in the records of Dao'an. The Sutra of Ananda's Recitation of the Buddha in two scrolls, also called the Sutra of Ananda's Recitation of the Dharma.

Jingmian Wang Jing, 1 fascicle, seen in the Records of the Tripiá¹­aka; Chawei Wang Jing, 1 fascicle, seen in the Records of Seng You; Fanhuang Wang Jing, 1 fascicle, seen in the Records of Seng You and the Biographies of Eminent Monks; Quan Fangbian Jing, 1 fascicle, seen in the Wu Catalog and other catalogs; Zuoxian Jing, 1 fascicle, seen in the Wu Catalog and other catalogs; Pusa Erbaiwufa Jing, 1 fascicle, sometimes 2 fascicles.

He presented this to Cao Shuang as a substitute for the 250 precepts for monks. The Fajing Jing Jie Zizhu, 2 fascicles, with preface; Daoshui Jing Annotation, 1 fascicle, with preface; Anban Jing Annotation, 1 fascicle, with preface. A total of 14 works.
Combined into 29 fascicles.
During the Zhengshi years of the Wei Qiwang era.
The Indian Å›ramaá¹‡a Kang Senghui.
He studied the Tripiá¹­aka and was well-versed in the Six Classics.
He was well-versed in astronomy, diagrams, and the classics.
He was eloquent and skilled in writing.
At that time, Zhi Qian of the three Wu regions had already propagated the translation of scriptures.
Since the initial infection of the great Dharma wind and transformation were not yet complete,
Seng Hui wanted to make the Way flourish in the Jiang Huai region and establish a monastery.
He then took his staff and traveled east.
In the years of the Wu Red Sparrow, he arrived in Jianye.
He immediately built a thatched hut, set up an image, and practiced the Way.
At that time, there were no monks, and they suspected his strange behavior.
The authorities reported to Sun Quan, who summoned him for questioning.
What spiritual evidence does the Buddha have?
You alone change your appearance.
Hui said, Since the Tathagata's passing, it has been over a thousand years.
His remaining bones are called 'relics' in the world.
Wherever they are, they manifest spiritual light in all directions.
In the past, when King Asoka ruled Jambudvipa,
he built 84,000 jeweled stupas.
The establishment of stupas and temples is to show the remaining teachings.
Quan considered it boastful.
He said,
If you can obtain relics, I will build a stupa for you.
If it is false, the country has a fixed punishment.
He requested seven days.
Hui told his followers,
The rise and fall of the Dharma depends on this one effort.
If we are not sincere now, what will we do in the future?
They then purified themselves, filled a copper vase with water, burned incense, and made offerings for seven days, but there was complete silence.
They requested to continue for another two seven-day periods, but there was still no response.
Sun Quan said,
This is a great deception. I am about to punish them.
They requested three more seven-day periods.
Quan again specially allowed it.
Hui said to his companions,
Confucius said,
'After King Wen passed away, did the Way not exist here?'
The Dharma is spiritual and should descend, but we have no response.
How can we rely on the king's laws?
We should vow to die as our deadline.
After three seven-day periods, it was evening and they still had not seen anything.
No one was not shaken with fear.
When it was past the fifth watch, they suddenly heard a loud sound from inside the vase.
Hui went to look and found that they had indeed obtained relics.
The next morning, they presented them to Quan.
The entire court gathered to observe.
Five-colored light and flames illuminated the top of the vase.
Quan himself held the vase and poured the contents onto a copper plate.
The stone case was immediately shattered.
Sun Quan was greatly startled and stood up, saying,
This is an auspicious sign!
Hui continued, saying,
The majestic spiritual power of the relic is not only its radiant appearance.ğŸ”½Even the fire at the end of the eon cannot burn it,
and the vajra hammer cannot crush it.
Sun Quan ordered a test.
Hui made another vow, saying,
The Dharma cloud is about to cover, and the people look up to the grace.
I wish you would further manifest spiritual traces to widely show your majestic spiritual power.
He then placed the relic on an iron anvil
and ordered a strong man to strike it with a hammer.
The anvil and hammer both sank in, but the relic was undamaged.
Sun Quan greatly sighed in admiration and immediately built a stupa for it.
Because it was the first Buddhist temple, it was called Jianchu Temple.
He named the area where it was located Futu Lane.
Thus, the great Dharma in Jiangzuo was finally established.
This was due to Hui's efforts.
During the time of Sun Hao, the laws were harsh and tyrannical, and he abolished licentious sacrifices.
and the Buddhist monasteries, all wanting to destroy them.
Hao asked his ministers,
Why did this happen? There must be a sacred spirit.
Should we follow his teachings?
If not, we can completely burn them.
The ministers all said,
The power of the Buddha is not the same as other spirits.
Kang Senghui felt the spirit and the great emperor founded the monastery.
Now if we lightly defame it, we fear it will bring misfortune in the future.
Hao's intention was not yet clear.
He then sent Zhang Xu to the monastery to question Senghui.
Xu's skillful eloquence was difficult to question and his arguments were extensive.
Senghui responded to the situation with eloquent words.
From dawn to dusk, Xu was unable to defeat him. Xu requested to withdraw.
Senghui saw him out the gate.
At that time, there was a house of licentious worship next to the monastery.
Xu also vowed,
If the Buddhist teachings are truly effective, why can't these people be reformed?
Senghui said,
Thunder and lightning strike, but the deaf do not hear.
How can it be that the sound is weak? It is important to understand the principle.

If it is not the right person, it will be like a house on fire.
Yu returned and sighed, saying, The gathering of talents and wisdom is not something I can fathom.
I humbly wish that the heavenly mirror will personally examine and investigate it.
Hao gathered the court officials and welcomed Hui with a horse carriage.
When Hui was seated,
Hao asked, What are the teachings of Buddhism about the retribution of good and evil?
What is it?
Hui replied, The teachings of Buddhism say that when a wise ruler teaches the world with filial piety and kindness, then red-crested birds will fly and the star of the elder will appear.
When benevolent virtue nurtures beings, then sweet springs will gush forth and auspicious seedlings will grow.
Since good has signs, evil can also be verified.
Therefore, if one does evil in secret,
the ghosts will punish it.
If one does evil in the open,
humans will kill it.
The Book of Poetry says, 'Seeking blessings does not turn back.'
The Book of Changes says, 'Accumulating goodness brings blessings.'
Although this is the standard teaching of Confucianism,
it is also the clear admonition of Buddhism.
Hao said, If that is so, then since Confucius and Mencius have already practiced it, why use Buddhism?
Hui said, Yes.
What Confucius and Laozi taught is to show the world briefly.
The teachings of the Buddha are profound and extensively clarify cause and effect.
Therefore, if one does evil, there will be eternal suffering in hell;
If one cultivates goodness, one will enjoy long-lasting happiness in the heavenly palace.
Using this to illustrate and encourage, isn't it great?
Although Sun Hao could not refute it and heard the true Dharma, his violent nature could not overcome his cruelty.
Once he ordered the guards of the inner palace to tend the garden.
They found a golden statue several feet tall.
He then presented it to Hao.
Hao ordered it placed in an impure place and filthy liquid poured over it.
He laughed with the ministers, taking it as entertainment.
Soon Hao's entire body became greatly swollen.
His private parts were especially painful.
He screamed as if reaching to the heavens.
The ministers lost color.
The court astrologer divined that he had offended a great deity.
He immediately prayed to the temples but did not recover.
The palace ladies who previously followed the Buddha's teachings
then asked him, saying:
Has Your Majesty ever sought blessings from the Buddha?
Hao raised his head and asked, Is the Buddha's spirit great?
The court ladies replied,
The Buddha is a great spirit.
Hao's mind was then enlightened.
Because he fully expressed his thoughts.
At that time, the court ladies welcomed the image and placed it in the hall.
They bathed it with fragrant hot water for dozens of times.
They burned incense and repented.
Hao kowtowed and apologized, thinking of the pillow and confessing his crimes.
After a while, the pain subsided. He sent a messenger to the temple to greet the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
He invited HuÃ¬ to expound the Dharma.
HuÃ¬ immediately followed him in.
Hao fully inquired about the principles of sin and merit.
HuÃ¬ explained them in a very concise and essential way.
Hao, who originally had talent and learning, was delighted and greatly pleased.
He sought to read the monks' precepts.
HuÃ¬ considered the precepts to be secret and not to be lightly proclaimed.
He then took the one hundred twenty-five vows of the Bodhisattva's Fundamental Practices.
He divided them into two hundred fifty matters.
He held them to correspond to the two hundred fifty precepts for fully ordained monks.
He used them to present to Hao.

Hao saw that the Buddha's actions, dwelling, sitting, and lying down all wished for sentient beings to attain peace and happiness, and his compassion was vast and extensive, further increasing his wholesome intentions, and he gave rise to a mind of faith and trust.
He doubled his joy and his sincere effort was vigorous.
He then invited Hui to receive the five precepts.
In a few days, his illness was cured.
He then further adorned Hui's temple.
He proclaimed it to the imperial clan, and none did not have faith and reverence.
Hui often expounded the true Dharma in the Wu court.
Hao's nature was fierce and coarse, and he was not tainted by subtle meanings.
He only narrated karmic retribution to open his mind.
And Hui, in his spare time, prayed for the assembly.
He translated the above sutras at Jianchu Temple and also annotated them himself.
The prefaces are all wonderfully in accord with the essence, and the meaning of the text is fully understood.
The sutras he annotated, such as Anban Shouyi, Fajing, and Daoshu,
are all seen in the catalog.
He also transmitted the sound of Sanskrit chanting, which was very clear, graceful, mournful, and sonorous, with a melodious tune.
Even today, people imitate it.
In the fourth month of the fourth year of the Tianji era in Wu, Hao surrendered to the Jin.
The ninth month, the assembly ended.

These are scriptures of unknown translators from the ancient and old two catalogs.
Now they are appended here to show the distant years and the basis of reliance.
A Record of the Three Treasures Throughout the Successive Reigns, Volume 5, Translated Scriptures of the Wei and Wu Dynasties
